ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: lectures were recorded
student presentations during live virtual seminar
This class was a once-weekly virtual seminar. However, the professor frequently met virtually with students outside of class-time to discuss projects and assignments.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is a good way to familiarize yourself with game theory literature
mathematical game theory, dynamic games, industrial organization: how can firms sustain collusion in the presence of demand shocks, imperfect information.
key areas of application of dynamic game theory, such as business cycles, time consistency, adverse selection. ability to read academic papers and present key findings
I learned more about dynamic games in the context of collusion and trust/relationships between agents
I learned the basics of game theory and the basics of repeated games in particular. We also learned how to read game theory papers and how to understand their methodology, models, and results.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course did an adequate job of touching on key topics in game theory, but the papers discussed were generally decades old and incredibly dry. I think this course would have benefitted from better signposting of important vs unimportant material within papers.

We cover a lot of papers, which was good for learning about dynamic games and various models. A weakness is that assignments did not have rubrics, and so grading is somewhat worrisome. Also maybe having more low-stake assignments as opposed to a few high-stake assignments would be better.

The professor is very approachable and always helpful and detailed in her responses to questions and comments. Great guidance given during presentation preparation which helped students internalize content and pick out key points of the papers.
I really enjoyed the opportunity to learn about the game theory literature through student presentations, but I would have preferred more lectures.

I think the greatest strength of this course was the interactive/presentation-style format whereby students would present a paper each week. This really forced us to dive deeply into the material- so much that we could present it in our own words. However, I do wish this was balanced better by a more thorough covering of the basic theory in addition to the presentations. By the middle of the semester, I felt kind of lost in all of the presentations and would have liked to spend more time on the game theory concepts and theory behind them as well. I definitely missed/did not understand a few of the concepts up front which led to greater and greater confusion over the course of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Recorded lectures were available, which was good. The course met once a week, and had no regular exams/homework aside from readings. This was all helpful for virtual engagement.
Use of Zoom was good

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you really like game theory, this course will be interesting and enjoyable. If you don't, or have limited desire to read dense academic literature, maybe find something else
If you are a fan of game theory and dynamic games (with the appropriate math background), then I would recommend. If not, then no.

Yes! Workload is quite low, just two papers and two presentations. Meets once a week. But student presentations can be quite dry and boring, and discussions sometimes aren't that fruitful as not everyone reads the papers assigned. Hopefully Prof AS can make the discussions more engaging by discussing more of her own thoughts on the issue-at-hand, rather than leaving it completely free for all.
Yes, but only if theyre very interested in game theory and have taken a basic game theory course before, preferably 351.

No I wouldnt. It is not structured in a way that facilitates any learning and there is just an immense amount of pressure on prsentateur in days and the two other assignments we have. Class is also not engaging

Yes, though I might recommend that interested students consider taking another course in game theory first if they do not have a decent understanding of the material already. I found it somewhat difficult to take this course as the only game theory course I've taken. I would also caution prospective students that this is not an "easy" senior seminar. To get the most of this course, you need to read and understand difficult material carefully.
